description:
Mytilus galloprovincialis, commonly known as the Mediterranean mussel, is a species of marine bivalve mollusk in the family Mytilidae. It is a type of edible sea mussel, closely related to the more widely distributed Mytilus edulis, the common mussel.

Mytilus galloprovincialis is native to the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea, but it has been introduced to various parts of the world, including the Pacific coast of North America, South America, South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand, where it has become an invasive species in some regions.

The shell of Mytilus galloprovincialis is typically dark blue or purple in color, with a smooth, glossy surface. The species can grow up to 12 cm in length, although the average size is typically around 5-8 cm. Mytilus galloprovincialis is a filter-feeding bivalve, consuming plankton and other suspended organic matter from the water column.

The species is widely cultivated for human consumption, and it is an important commercial and aquaculture resource in many parts of the world. Mytilus galloprovincialis is also an important component of coastal ecosystems, serving as a food source for various predators and playing a role in nutrient cycling and habitat formation.
